paragraph: Eric often talked now of work in this slighting way partly as an excuse for the low places in form to which he was gradually sinking. Everybody knew that had he properly exerted his abilities he was capable of beating almost any boy; so, to quiet his conscience, he professed to ridicule diligence as an unboyish piece of muffishness, and was never slow to sneer at the "grinders," as he contemptuously called all those who laid themselves out to win school distinctions.

paragraph: Eric had grown very touchy lately about advice, particularly from any fellow of his own standing; and after the checks he had recently received, a coolness had sprung up between him and nearly all the study-boys, which made him more than ever inclined to assert his independence, and defy and thwart them in every way.

paragraph: "Keep your advice to yourself, Duncan, till it's asked for," he answered, roughly. "You've done nothing but _advise_ lately, and I'm rather sick of it."

paragraph: "Comme vous voulez," replied Duncan, with a shrug. "Gang your own gait; I'll have nothing more to do with trying to stop you, since you _will_ ruin yourself."

paragraph: Nothing more was said in the study that evening, and when Eric went down he didn't even bid Duncan goodnight.

paragraph: "Charlie," he said, as he stole on tiptoe into Wildney's dormitory.

paragraph: Eric went and sat by him, and he sat up in his bed "First of all, _you're_ to keep awake till twelve to-night," he whispered; "old Rowley'll have gone round by that time, and it'll be all safe. Then come and awake me again, and I'll watch till one, Pietrie till two, and Graham till three. Then Graham'll awake us all, and we'll dress."

paragraph: Eric went to his room and lay down, but he didn't take off his clothes, for fear he should go to sleep. Dr. Rowlands came round as usual at eleven, and then Eric closed his eyes for a few minutes, till the head-master had disappeared. After that he lay awake thinking for an hour, but his thoughts weren't very pleasant.

paragraph: In ten minutes he had silently shot back the lock with the old nail, and the boys were on the landing. They carried their shoes in their hands, ran noiselessly down stairs, and went to the same window at which Eric and Wildney had got out before. Wildney had taken care beforehand to break the pane and move away the glass, so they had only to loosen the bar and slip through one by one.

paragraph: It was cold and very dark, and as on the March morning they stood out in the playground, all four would rather have been safe and harmlessly in bed. But the novelty and the excitement of the enterprise bore them up, and they started off quickly for the house at which Mr. Gordon and his pupils lived, which was about half a mile from the school. They went arm in arm to assure each other a little, for at first in their fright they were inclined to take every post and tree for a man in ambush, and to hear a recalling voice in every sound of wind and wave.
tokens: cold dark morning stand playground safe bed novelty excitement enterprise bear start house pupil live mile school go arm arm assure other little first fright inclined take post tree man ambush hear recall voice sound wind wave

paragraph: Not far from Mr. Gordon's was a carpenter's shop, and outside of this there was generally a ladder standing. They had arranged to carry this ladder with them (as it was only a short one), climb the low garden wall with it, and then place it against the house, immediately under the dovecot which hung by the first story-windows. Wildney, as the lightest of the four, was to take the birds, while the others held the ladder.
tokens: carpenter shop ladder standing arrange carry ladder short one climb low garden wall place house dovecot hang first story window light take bird other hold ladder

paragraph: Slanting it so that it should be as far from the side of the window as possible, Wildney ascended and thrust both hands into the cot. He succeeded in seizing a pigeon with each hand, but in doing so threw the other birds into a state of such alarm that they fluttered about in the wildest manner, and the moment his hands were withdrawn, flew out with a great flapping of hurried wings.
tokens: slant side window possible ascend thrust hand cot succeed seize pigeon hand do throw other bird state such alarm flutter wild manner moment hand withdraw fly great flap hurry wing

paragraph: The noise they made alarmed the plunderer, and he hurried down the ladder as fast as he could. He handed the pigeons to the others, who instantly wrung their necks.

paragraph: "I'm nearly sure I heard somebody stir," said Wildney; "we haven't been half quiet enough. Here! let's crouch down in this corner."

paragraph: All four shrank up as close to the wall as they could, and held their breath. Some one was certainly stirring, and at last they heard the window open. A head was thrust out, and Mr. Gordon's voice asked sternly--"Who's there?"

paragraph: "Run for your lives," said Eric hurriedly; "it's Gordon, and he's raising the alarm."

paragraph: "No, Charlie, I won't;" and grasping his hand, Eric hurried him over the style and through the fields, while Pietrie and Graham took the opposite direction.

paragraph: Some one (they did not know who it was, but suspected it to be Mr. Gordon's servant-man) was running after them, and they could distinctly hear his footsteps, which seemed to be half a field distant. He carried a light, and they heard him panting. They were themselves tired, and in the utmost trepidation; the usually courageous Wildney was trembling all over, and his fear communicated itself to Eric. Horrible visions of a trial for burglary, imprisonment in the castle jail, and perhaps transportation, presented themselves to their excited imaginations, as the sound of the footsteps came nearer.
tokens: one know suspect servant man run hear footstep seem field distant carry light hear pant tired utmost trepidation courageous tremble fear communicate horrible vision trial burglary imprisonment castle jail transportation present excited imagination sound footstep come

paragraph: "I can't run any further, Eric," said Wildney. "What shall we do? don't leave me, for heaven's sake."
tokens: run say do leave heaven sake

paragraph: "Not I, Charlie. We must hide the minute we get t'other side of this hedge."
tokens: hide minute get t'other side hedge

paragraph: They scrambled over the gate, and plunged into the thickest part of a plantation close by, lying down on the ground behind some bushes, and keeping as still as they could, taking care to cover over their white collars.
tokens: scramble gate plunge thickest part plantation lie ground bush keep take care cover white collar

paragraph: The pursuer reached the gate, and no longer hearing footsteps in front of him, he paused. He went a little distance up the hedge on both sides and held up his light, but did not detect the cowering boys, and at last giving up the search in despair, went slowly home. They heard him plodding back over the field, and it was not until the sound of his footsteps had died away, that Eric cautiously broke cover, and looked over the hedge. He saw the man's light gradually getting more distant, and said, "All right now, Charlie. We must make the best of our way home."

paragraph: "Quite; come along. I only hope Pietrie and Graham ain't caught."

paragraph: They got back about half-past four, and climbed in unheard and undetected through the window pane. They then stole up stairs with beating hearts, and sat in Eric's room to wait for the other two. To their great relief they heard them enter the lavatory about ten minutes after.

paragraph: "No," said Graham; "precious near it though. Old Gordon and some men were after us, but at last we doubled rather neatly, and escaped them. It's all serene, and we shan't be caught."

paragraph: "Well, we'd best to bed now," said Eric; "and, to my thinking, we should be wise to keep a quiet tongue in our heads about this affair."
tokens: good bed say thinking wise keep quiet tongue head affair

paragraph: "Yes, we had better tell _no one_." They agreed, and went off to bed again. So, next morning, they all four got up quite as if nothing had happened, and made no allusion to the preceding night, although, they could not help chuckling inwardly a little when the Gordonites came to morning school, brimful of a story about their house having been attacked in the night by thieves, who, after bagging some pigeons, had been chevied by Gordon and the servants. Wildney professed immense interest in the incident, and asked many questions, which showed that there was not a shadow of suspicion in any one's mind as to the real culprits.
tokens: have good tell _no one_ agree go bed next morning get happen make allusion preced night help chuckle little come morning school brimful story house attack night thief bagg pigeon chevied servant profess immense interest incident ask many question show be shadow suspicion mind real culprit

paragraph: Carter, the school servant, didn't seem to have noticed that the lavatory door was unlocked, and Mr. Harley never alluded again to his disturbance in the night. So the theft of the pigeons remained undiscovered, and remains so till this day. If any old Roslyn boy reads this veracious history, he will doubtless be astounded to hear that the burglars on that memorable night were Brio, Pietrie, Graham, and Wildney.
tokens: school servant seem notice lavatory door unlock allude disturbance night theft pigeon remain undiscovered remain day old boy read veracious history astound hear burglar memorable night
